messageBody:
Jason Rogers <jacaetevha@...> wrote - in reply to Cedric:
> > >
> > > Unit Tests are real safety. Static typing is the illusion of
> > > safety, I choose the former.
> >
> >
> > Code that uses both will always be safer than code that only uses one of
> > these.
> That is a very striking statement. Are you saying that (in your opinion)
> static languages are inherently safer than dynamic languages?

Here is my experience (although this could probably be derided as "opinion",
couldn't it?):

* I have written a complete OR mapping (which is in productive use in about
6 projects of a large retail company) in Java. Java's (JDK1.2) collections
have dynamic typing for their contents. Using quite explicit naming
conventions so that parameters, instance variables and local variables spell
their type quite directly (childAssocNodes for a collection of
AbstractAssociationNodes), no single letter names even for local vars etc.,
I felt quite comfortable with this. A similar experience from a
smaller-sized Smalltalk project (about people, about 1 year) about 10 years
ago was the same.

* Still, when I converted a few larger tools to JDK1.5 (up to now, alas, not
the large ORMapping) it felt like "finally being there".
I have also written a library for bidirectional associations in C#, using
C#'s generics. The "good feeling" (ok - it's opinion after all ...) that you
do not even need to run the (in that case, extensive and written TDD-style)
unit tests, because you can be sure that "if it compiles, it is correct", is
something that helps (me) very much when writing intricate algorithms.

However, these experiences may be because I am a "static thinker": The
mathematical concepts of static invariants and other static constraints are
a main technique for me when designing algorithms. As far as I know, there
are many more "execution type people" around who need something that "runs"
to be "emotionally happy".

Maybe this explains that (to me sometimes "religious") discussion on static
vs. dynamic typing - might it be the old difference between the "let's
compute it!"-type engineer and the "let's build/try it!"-type engineer? -
where both have their well-founded arsenal of tools to support their
techniques - e.g. redundant over-the-thumb-checks against reality in the
case of the "static computation" guy, scaffolding/mocks/test runs in the
case of the "executing" guy - and are quite happy with it?

... but probably that's now too much "laymean's philosophy" or something
like that ...

Regards
Harald M.
